ratings.comment: A very difficult professor. Every week a very difficult homework which counts only to a 20% of the class. There are 2 midterms and a final. Both midterms were difficult where mean was 60% for both. Grading was very strict. Final was more difficult.
This class is tougher than I think, but professor explain it so well. Remember to do all the homework and practice problems in the text book.
He communicates pretty well but I feel like I can't understand 30% of the concepts. Maybe he's bad at explaining or maybe I need to get off my phone during lecture, idk

Jun Le cares a lot about his students. Some people find Math 475 very hard, and others find it easy. He purposely doesn't go super in depth in certain things in order to not confuse most of the class. He takes feedback seriously, so speak up! If you have a problem or feel confused, say something.

He's not the smartest professor I've ever met, but he might be the nicest. Being a young guy himself you can really tell he remembers what it's like to be a student and he behaves accordingly. I have nothing bad to say about Jun Le Goh other than he tends to deflect some questions by saying "we don't have to worry about that in this course."
he is alright, definitly go to class and office hours and you will be fine

Prof Goh teaches what is an inherently hard course very well. One's first foray into proof based math will always be difficult until you put in the time, which is why I suspect there are so many low ratings. Prof Goh will try to help as much as possible, but make sure to put in the time to practice if you want to do well in proof based math.

He definitely knows his stuff and has a passion to teach. One of the better Math profs I've seen at UW. Homeworks were very helpful for learning. Contents were a bit difficult, but he provides lecture slides and past homework answers to assist you. He answers questions very diligently on piazza, which was really nice. Recommend!
He knows his material but cannot explain it as well. Ok at best, you will have to do the work on your own and a good TA will be really important (a good study group will also suffice).

Jun Les teaching style is perfectly suited for the 2% of the population that are born with high mathematical intuition. He covers each concept once, does one sample problem for each, and moves on, never to return. You are not taught how to write proofs, just assumed to be capable and given devilishly difficult homework and exams.
UW Madison has a terrible Math Department, Jun follows the rep. You must put in 15-20 hours a week in his class in order to earn a good grade.

Like most math professors at the Univerisity of Wisconsin-Madison, Jun Le Goh lacks communication amongst students, holds fast-paced lectures with little to none explanation for proofs, and has high expectations for an intro discrete math class. Attending Lectures vs Book? I initially attended, however the book was more efficient and understandab.
One of the better math professors at UW

Professor Goh endlessly talks in class about the material and then gives homework that is somewhat based on the material. You have to do a lot of learning on your own to do well in the class. He is a nice guy that really knows the material, but he is not the best at teaching it to his students.
He knows his stuff, but his teaching skills are not good.
